title: avoid rotation jumpiness
State a general principle for which d3 modules compete with React
body: Not sure about the exact phrasing but I think something like this would be nice. It'd be overwhelming to list every module that touches the DOM, but it may be frustratingly vague to just say "most don't, some do". Is there a general principle by which the uninitiated reader might spot which do and don't? As a beginner programmer learning D3 I know I didn't have a good mental model of where the DOM fit in, but I think I'd at least be able to spot "does this take a selection".

title: two more anchors… hopefully the last
reference all projections incl. d3-geo-projection and d3-geo-polygon
body:
It's a lot, but we love projections, and it would be a shame not to find them with instant search.

I've put everything into a single file, but it's possibly too much. Leaving this as a draft for discussion:

We could:
* remove the d3-geo projections and split the remainder again into two groups (geo-projection vs geo-polygon), but that's still a long list and there are duplicates)
* create another type of classification? (polyhedral, etc)
* move the “additional methods” (geoProject…) in their own page, and have only projections in that page

title: fix broken anchors
Add short "D3 in React" section
body: I know you removed the TODO but I was already trying to fill it in! I think just making the distinction of modules that touch the DOM and those that don't was super clarifying for me personally when I figured that out. And I always forget the most basic ref pattern (and still might've messed it up here). I don't think we should get into updating or interactivity or whatever, but I think just this much goes a long way toward demystifying (and showing just the most basic best practices).

title: Complex charting solution required
body:
I would like to build a report of the sample which I have attached. Can you please tell me if this is possible using D3.
In my report lots of charts are displayed. Like 1 for Heart Rate, Temperature, Respiration Rate and so on. I refer to this as a chart section below.

Some of the features that I require in my reports are mentioned below. Chart should be able to behave as a chart to display various chart types along with that it should also be able to display as a tabular view to display data in each cell. Some sections display charts like line chart or bar chart or combination of more than 2 chart types in a single chart or tabular format.
I have attached a PDF which has a sample type of charts that I require along with the below lists indicated in that chart for more clarity.

	1. The Chart section should be able to show in the form of a grid.
	2. In each grid cell I should be able to show a text - Tabular chart.
	3. Should be able to strikethrough a column completely with a red line
	4. Should be able to leave a vertical line space inside the chart based upon some logical conditions that we have (for ex, if the patient has a 24 hours of gap between the observations then we should show a vertical gap)
	5. Should be able to add a legend on the right side. Sometimes the legend should be mapped to a chart section (in such case legend should be aligned against the chart section row) , sometimes it can be common to all the chart sections. Here the chart section I refer to as heart rate, respiration rate and so on.
	6. I should be able to show multiple graph types in a single chart section - refer multiplegraphs-1 attachment
	7. In the chart section the ranges are shown as a separate label which needs to be aligned to the chart grid rows. Is this possible within the chart or we need a separate control which needs to be aligned to the chart rows.
	8. The chart section should not span across pages.
	9. Multiple Y-axis. Not sure if we will have multiple x-axis. But multiple y-axis.
	10. Does it support all the browsers and mobile devices like android and ios?
	11. Can we have an interactive chart?
	12. Does it have 3D support?
	13. Can we place an icon inside the chart grid cell?
	14. Can we show an overlay on the chart?
	15. Can we write a display a letter with an exponential like A to the power of 2
	16. To how much extent can we compress the chart to fit more pages and the font is still visible and looks nice
	17. Zooming option
	18. Panning
horizontal scrolling- this could be a separate chart altogether. please refer horizontal-scrolling-chart attachment
I have marked the numbers in the chart. Please look at the chart. And let me know if all these are possible or not. If possible, can you build a code pen project of the sample report which I have attached -ptn0445789-EWSReport-2 (1) . I can play around with that. May be one in client side with multiple pages to see the performance impact as well

I have attached 2 images and 2 pdf files. Please have a look at all of them. Mainly at the PDFs first

[ptn0445789-EWSReport-2 (1).pdf](https://github.com/d3/d3/files/11672913/ptn0445789-EWSReport-2.1.pdf)
![multiplegraphs-1chartsection](https://github.com/d3/d3/assets/5516586/221507ae-bee3-4e5d-95f7-0c8ac67b5f79)
![horizontal-scrolling-chart](https://github.com/d3/d3/assets/5516586/1122a3e7-b6f5-4483-a097-ba7af0d403ee)

title: Circular dependencies in d3-selection, d3-interpolate, and d3-transition
body:
Several d3 modules are a dependency for @carbon/charts. During builds, several circular dependencies have been identified. These need to be resolved...
```
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/select.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/selectAll.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js

title: Zooming to a certain point instead of mouse position
body:
I'm using d3@7.3.0, and I would like to make a zoomable/pannable timeline with d3 zoom and a d3 timescale. My issue is that I want the timeline to zoom in and out of the center of the timeline as opposed to where my mouse position is. Here is my current behaviour: 
![chrome-capture-2023-2-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97198784/225365816-d299afea-3b24-4a4b-a609-056aec4c1cee.gif)

And an example behaviour that I would like it to follow (note the zooming being on the center point of the timeline):
![AcsClient_XlkGMni9iu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97198784/225367780-57f6a287-5912-4068-9fe0-2511dc448fbf.gif)

I've noticed that older versions of d3 had the zoom.center() function that seemed to cater to this behaviour, ([an example that used it in a similar way to what I want](https://observablehq.com/d/48ff4a64c477cc79)) but it doesn't exist anymore. What would be the best way to implement this? Here is a general layout of my current code for reference as well (very simple of course):
```
const scale = d3
        .scaleTime()
        .domain([thirtyMinsAgo, now])
        .range([0, timelineWidth - 1])

const zoom = d3
        .zoom()
        .scaleExtent([0.0025, 250])
        .on('zoom', ({ transform }) => {
          scaleRef.current = transform.rescaleX(scale);
          scaleTimeline(scaleRef.current);
        })

svg.call(zoom);
```

CI: Set minimum permissions on GitHub Workflow
body:
Hi!

I'd like to suggest the addition of top-level minimal permissions on your workflow, as it would harden your security agains supply-chain attacks.

I see that you have only one workflow, the [node.js.yml](https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/main/.github/workflows/node.js.yml), but it does not specify the permissions for its jobs, letting their privileges determined by GitHub's defaults. By defining minimal permissions you would be secured against erroneous or malicious actions from external jobs you call from your workflow. It's specially important for the case they get compromised, for example.

Setting minimum permissions for workflows is recommended by [GitHub itself](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication) and also by other security tools, such as [Scorecards](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard) and [StepSecurity](https://github.com/step-security).

I'd be happy to raise a PR with the changes if you agree.

#### Context
I'm Diogo and I work on Google's Open Source Security Team([GOSST](https://github.com/diogoteles08#about-gosst-ghost)) suggesting and implementing security changes on critical open source projects :blush:

title: As a beginner I am having problem in including the gradient color in edges of a force directed graph.
Apparent case of Chicken and Egg when updating nodes
body:
I'll preface with a disclaimer that I might be using the library wrong.  Still, it would be helpful to know what the expected answer to this problem is.  Roughly what I'm doing:

1. Have a `var simNodes` that contains the nodes used for the sims.
2. Have a `var simLinks` that contains the links used.
3. Remove a node (let's call it `node11`) from simNodes along with any simLinks entry that references it.
4. Call `simulation.nodes(simNodes)` to remove the node from the simulation.
5. Call `simulation.force("links").links(simLinks)` to remove the forces that were acting on that node.
6. Call alpha and restart to kick the graph into action.

After a bunch of debugging I discovered that the problem I'm running into is that the objects in `simLinks` have `source` and `target` defined as getters instead of just references.  When a force that acted on `node11` was evaluated by the simulation the getter  would return the entry in `simNodes` for `node11` ... which is fine if the node exists, but those links are getting evaluated after I removed the node and that's a problem.  I thought I had accidentally left a link somehow but couldn't find a source.  Much digging later I found this note:

> [#](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#simulation_nodes) simulation.nodes([nodes]) · [Source](https://github.com/d3/d3-force/blob/master/src/simulation.js)
> 
> If nodes is specified, sets the simulation’s nodes to the specified array of objects, initializing their positions and velocities if necessary, and then [re-initializes](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#force_initialize) any bound [forces](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#simulation_force); returns the simulation.

Re-initializes the forces?  Eh?  Further down, forceLink says...

> When the link force is [initialized](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#force_initialize) (or re-initialized, as when the nodes or links change), any link.source or link.target property which is not an object is replaced by an object reference to the corresponding node with the given identifier.

So, if I'm understanding all this correctly, updating either the nodes or links causes an evaluation of the source and target of all links, which in this case means step 4 triggers access of the links before I can update them in step 5.  If I flip those two steps, so I update the links before nodes, I'll hit the same issue when adding nodes instead.  If I have a change set that both adds and removes nodes I'd get the error regardless of which I tried to update first.

I know the obvious answer here is to not use a getter but I'd prefer to keep them if possible.  Another obvious answer would be to return a dummy object, but that feels event worse.  Looking at the code, though, it seems like the same issue exists when links are referenced by identifier like in the second quote...

https://github.com/d3/d3-force/blob/main/src/link.js#L58
```    for (i = 0, count = new Array(n); i < m; ++i) {
      link = links[i], link.index = i;
      if (typeof link.source !== "object") link.source = find(nodeById, link.source);
      if (typeof link.target !== "object") link.target = find(nodeById, link.target);
      count[link.source.index] = (count[link.source.index] || 0) + 1;
      count[link.target.index] = (count[link.target.index] || 0) + 1;
    }```

It seems to me that if initialize gets called with links where the source or target are identifiers, and that identifier refers to a node not in the sim, find throws an error and the call to links() fails.  Since the property is overwritten it shouldn't be an issue when removing nodes, no lookup is done in that case.  It would be a problem if you tried to add to the simulation though, specifically when adding the link before adding the node.

Thoughts?  Is there a sensible way to do this without making `.source` and `.target` be objects?  Is there supposed to be an order for updating the nodes and forces?

For the time being I'm using a work around of calling `simulation.force("links").links([])" before updating the node list in step 4, so as to change the node list while there's no links present, but that's not exactly optimal.

```html
<html>
  <head>
    <script type="module">
      import * as d3 from "https://cdn.skypack.dev/d3@7";
      const div = d3.selectAll("div");
      </script>

</html>
```

This is what I get in the console on Chrome 108.0.5359.98 on Ventura 13.0.1 (22A400)

```
build:d3@v7.7.0-bA10BcqHRoGFDOMeGCpC:14 [Package Error] "d3@v7.7.0" could not be built. 
[1/5] Verifying package is valid…
[2/5] Installing dependencies from npm…
No matching version found for d3@7.7.0.

using `d3@6` on skypack works fine. FWIW, esm.sh does work for both `@6` and `@7`:

```
import * as d3 from "https://esm.sh/d3@7";

title: Circular dependencies in d3-selection, d3-interpolate, and d3-transition
body:
Several d3 modules are a dependency for @carbon/charts. During builds, several circular dependencies have been identified. These need to be resolved...
```
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/select.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/selectAll.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/filter.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/data.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/data.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/enter.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/exit.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/merge.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/sort.js -> node_modules/d3-selection/src/selection/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-interpolate/src/value.js -> node_modules/d3-interpolate/src/array.js -> node_modules/d3-interpolate/src/value.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-interpolate/src/value.js -> node_modules/d3-interpolate/src/object.js -> node_modules/d3-interpolate/src/value.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/filter.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/merge.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/select.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/selectAll.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js
Circular dependency: node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/transition.js -> node_modules/d3-transition/src/transition/index.js
```

title: Zooming to a certain point instead of mouse position
body:
I'm using d3@7.3.0, and I would like to make a zoomable/pannable timeline with d3 zoom and a d3 timescale. My issue is that I want the timeline to zoom in and out of the center of the timeline as opposed to where my mouse position is. Here is my current behaviour: 
![chrome-capture-2023-2-15](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97198784/225365816-d299afea-3b24-4a4b-a609-056aec4c1cee.gif)

And an example behaviour that I would like it to follow (note the zooming being on the center point of the timeline):
![AcsClient_XlkGMni9iu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/97198784/225367780-57f6a287-5912-4068-9fe0-2511dc448fbf.gif)

I've noticed that older versions of d3 had the zoom.center() function that seemed to cater to this behaviour, ([an example that used it in a similar way to what I want](https://observablehq.com/d/48ff4a64c477cc79)) but it doesn't exist anymore. What would be the best way to implement this? Here is a general layout of my current code for reference as well (very simple of course):
```
const scale = d3
        .scaleTime()
        .domain([thirtyMinsAgo, now])
        .range([0, timelineWidth - 1])

const zoom = d3
        .zoom()
        .scaleExtent([0.0025, 250])
        .on('zoom', ({ transform }) => {
          scaleRef.current = transform.rescaleX(scale);
          scaleTimeline(scaleRef.current);
        })

svg.call(zoom);
```

CI: Set minimum permissions on GitHub Workflow
body:
Hi!

I'd like to suggest the addition of top-level minimal permissions on your workflow, as it would harden your security agains supply-chain attacks.

I see that you have only one workflow, the [node.js.yml](https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/main/.github/workflows/node.js.yml), but it does not specify the permissions for its jobs, letting their privileges determined by GitHub's defaults. By defining minimal permissions you would be secured against erroneous or malicious actions from external jobs you call from your workflow. It's specially important for the case they get compromised, for example.

Setting minimum permissions for workflows is recommended by [GitHub itself](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication) and also by other security tools, such as [Scorecards](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard) and [StepSecurity](https://github.com/step-security).

I'd be happy to raise a PR with the changes if you agree.

#### Context
I'm Diogo and I work on Google's Open Source Security Team([GOSST](https://github.com/diogoteles08#about-gosst-ghost)) suggesting and implementing security changes on critical open source projects :blush:

title: Support SSR
body:
It would be great if D3 could be used in SSR. With SSR available, we can offload data fetching and SVG rendering to the server side.
I heard that `d3.select` API works only on the client side, so it cannot support SSR. If a DOM library that operates on the server side, such as jsdom, is adopted inside D3.js, it may be possible to render SVG on the server side, that is, with Node.js, etc., and use hydration on the client side to realize an interactive UI. Is it not?

title: Potential addition to the Tutorials wiki page
body:
Hi,

I'm the maintainer of two d3 related websites:
- the [d3 graph gallery](https://www.d3-graph-gallery.com) displays many simple charts made in pure d3
- the [react graph gallery](https://www.react-graph-gallery.com) does the same, but using d3 for math and react for rendering

I was wondering if those 2 projects could be listed in the [tutorials wiki page](https://github.com/d3/d3/wiki/Tutorials)?

Thanks so much for your work on this awesome d3 project.

Note: I tried to open a PR but it looks like the wiki is not open for contributions 🤔 
Note: I can offer my help to check all the links listed in this wiki page to double check if they are all still alive

title: Markers not reachable using keyboard [Accessibility issue]
body: We are using d3-geo to display worldmap with markers on few countries, while doing accessibility testing using [Accessibility Insights for Web](https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/web/overview/) extension, none of the markers(countries) are reachable using tab key. This is a serious concern for accessibility as the interactive elements are not reachable through keyboard. Please let me know if there is any fix for this issue.

title: As a beginner I am having problem in including the gradient color in edges of a force directed graph.
Apparent case of Chicken and Egg when updating nodes
body:
I'll preface with a disclaimer that I might be using the library wrong.  Still, it would be helpful to know what the expected answer to this problem is.  Roughly what I'm doing:

1. Have a `var simNodes` that contains the nodes used for the sims.
2. Have a `var simLinks` that contains the links used.
3. Remove a node (let's call it `node11`) from simNodes along with any simLinks entry that references it.
4. Call `simulation.nodes(simNodes)` to remove the node from the simulation.
5. Call `simulation.force("links").links(simLinks)` to remove the forces that were acting on that node.
6. Call alpha and restart to kick the graph into action.

After a bunch of debugging I discovered that the problem I'm running into is that the objects in `simLinks` have `source` and `target` defined as getters instead of just references.  When a force that acted on `node11` was evaluated by the simulation the getter  would return the entry in `simNodes` for `node11` ... which is fine if the node exists, but those links are getting evaluated after I removed the node and that's a problem.  I thought I had accidentally left a link somehow but couldn't find a source.  Much digging later I found this note:

> [#](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#simulation_nodes) simulation.nodes([nodes]) · [Source](https://github.com/d3/d3-force/blob/master/src/simulation.js)
> 
> If nodes is specified, sets the simulation’s nodes to the specified array of objects, initializing their positions and velocities if necessary, and then [re-initializes](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#force_initialize) any bound [forces](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#simulation_force); returns the simulation.

Re-initializes the forces?  Eh?  Further down, forceLink says...

> When the link force is [initialized](https://github.com/d3/d3-force#force_initialize) (or re-initialized, as when the nodes or links change), any link.source or link.target property which is not an object is replaced by an object reference to the corresponding node with the given identifier.

So, if I'm understanding all this correctly, updating either the nodes or links causes an evaluation of the source and target of all links, which in this case means step 4 triggers access of the links before I can update them in step 5.  If I flip those two steps, so I update the links before nodes, I'll hit the same issue when adding nodes instead.  If I have a change set that both adds and removes nodes I'd get the error regardless of which I tried to update first.

I know the obvious answer here is to not use a getter but I'd prefer to keep them if possible.  Another obvious answer would be to return a dummy object, but that feels event worse.  Looking at the code, though, it seems like the same issue exists when links are referenced by identifier like in the second quote...

https://github.com/d3/d3-force/blob/main/src/link.js#L58
```    for (i = 0, count = new Array(n); i < m; ++i) {
      link = links[i], link.index = i;
      if (typeof link.source !== "object") link.source = find(nodeById, link.source);
      if (typeof link.target !== "object") link.target = find(nodeById, link.target);
      count[link.source.index] = (count[link.source.index] || 0) + 1;
      count[link.target.index] = (count[link.target.index] || 0) + 1;
    }```

It seems to me that if initialize gets called with links where the source or target are identifiers, and that identifier refers to a node not in the sim, find throws an error and the call to links() fails.  Since the property is overwritten it shouldn't be an issue when removing nodes, no lookup is done in that case.  It would be a problem if you tried to add to the simulation though, specifically when adding the link before adding the node.

Thoughts?  Is there a sensible way to do this without making `.source` and `.target` be objects?  Is there supposed to be an order for updating the nodes and forces?

For the time being I'm using a work around of calling `simulation.force("links").links([])" before updating the node list in step 4, so as to change the node list while there's no links present, but that's not exactly optimal.

title: README.md issue: skypack.dev seems to not be resolving `d3@7` correctly
body:
(I think this is the right place to report, since the issue is on this repo. I did read the warning on the issue creator, but I think this applies. Sorry if it doesn't!)

It seems that `skypack.dev` is refusing to build d3 7.7 :(

```html
<html>
  <head>
    <script type="module">
      import * as d3 from "https://cdn.skypack.dev/d3@7";
      const div = d3.selectAll("div");
      </script>
    </head>
  <body></body>
</html>
```

This is what I get in the console on Chrome 108.0.5359.98 on Ventura 13.0.1 (22A400)

```
build:d3@v7.7.0-bA10BcqHRoGFDOMeGCpC:14 [Package Error] "d3@v7.7.0" could not be built. 
[1/5] Verifying package is valid…
[2/5] Installing dependencies from npm…
No matching version found for d3@7.7.0.
```

using `d3@6` on skypack works fine. FWIW, esm.sh does work for both `@6` and `@7`:

```
import * as d3 from "https://esm.sh/d3@7";
```
